data.title: This is Money: Be your own financial adviser
data.meta_description: Your complete guide to personal finance and investing with news, predictions, advice, guides and opinion from the financial website of the year.
data.text:
With global markets in turmoil, look closer to home for British bargains to bag in a perfect storm

There was an abrupt sell-off in global stock markets this week, sparked by fears of a US recession and the unwinding of bets on the Japanese currency, the yen. But, while volatility may continue, the audacious seem keen to scout out opportunities in the US, Japan - and the UK. If you are looking at your portfolio in the wake of the turbulence, taking a chance on some British names could be a useful diversification.

Tesco may be a stock to add to your shopping list if you are seeking more exposure to British shares

Tesco has been buying back its shares and intends to spend a further £1billion over the next year on this strategy. Share buybacks should boost the share price.

Insurers could have to pay millions in claims after foiled terror attack forced Taylor Swift concerts to be cancelled

Some 195,000 fans had been expected to attend the concerts in Vienna. But organisers had to scrap the concerts after a planned attack at the Ernst Happel Stadium.

Interactive Investor offers Sipp investors up to £2,000 to switch their pension - is it a deal worth taking?

In order to qualify, customers must transfer a pension worth at least £10,000. Up to £49,999, this will earn them £100 in cashback, with the amount available rising incrementally with the size of the transfer.

Landlords forced to pay £700 on average as more councils make them sign up to buy-to-let 'licence' scheme

Some councils require landlords to get 'selective licences' in the hope that this will improve standards - but the cost of these differs widely across the country.

Two years after landmark Highway Code rule was launched to protect cyclists and pedestrians, two fifths of drivers don't know it exists... or ignore it

A poll of almost 10,000 UK motorists revealed that 42% either don't know the rule exists or had heard about it but thought it was untrue.

MONEY NEWS & ADVICE

Savers warned to get their skates on to bag fixed-rates over 5% as top accounts could soon disappear

Top-fixed rate deals could fall below 5 per cent by the end of the month, savings experts have warned. Headline fixed-rate deals have been cut left, right and centre across different terms. This is Money analysis found that since the base rate was cut to 5% last week, at least 41 savings accounts have had their rates cut .

Disclose and pay tax on your crypto gains, HMRC reminds investors in strongly-worded letter

The disposal of crypto is generally treated the same as other common assets for tax purposes - and HMRC is chasing up those who may not have paid.

Can you get your money back if your package holiday is cancelled - and what does ATOL protection actually mean?

If you've booked a package trip and something goes wrong, you should be able to claw back the cash you forked out for two weeks relaxing on a beach.

You risk losing £500 if you trade in a car with on these warning lights on: Would it be cheaper to fix the problem first?

Owen Gregory, a professional vehicle appraiser at used car retailer Big Motoring World explains: 'When bringing your motor to us for part exchange, we want to know how well the car has been looked after because it directly affects how easy it will be for us to sell it.' He explains how much a dealer will reduce their trade-in price offer based on a car having any of these three warning lights on.

Swift new ride for chart topping Nissan Qashqai: And superstar singer is a big fan of the SUV, says RAY MASSEY

Nissan has given the top-selling Qashqai a facelift to sharpen up its style, interior technology and trim to bring it more in line with the all-electric Nissan Ariya.

I lost my ticket for a £12.50-a-day car park but NCP charged me a £300 fee: CRANE ON THE CASE

I parked at the train station while on a weekend away - and when returned I was slapped with a £100 per day 'lost ticket fee'.

EXCLUSIVEHow government EV sales targets have pushed car makers to use drastic tactics to force YOU to go green

The ZEV mandate - which requires car brands to sell an increasing number of EVs until 2035 or be fined - has triggered 'behaviour not seen in 40 years' in the motor industry. So what tactics are brands resorting to? This is Money spoke to MG UK commercial director Guy Pigounakis (pictured left) to understand the drastic strategies at play - from slashing prices to increasing demonstrator stock.

Second-hand electric car sales on the rise: Increased availability and rock bottom prices spark fresh demand

Used EVs sales grew 52.6% in the months of April to June thanks to increasing availability and rock bottom prices.

Would your car and home insurance policies pay out for riot damage? Your rights explained

Many shops, mosques and immigration centres have been targeted during recent rioting, but some cars and private homes have been damaged too.

Stock markets have a habit of freaking out - but you shouldn't: SIMON LAMBERT on how investors can ride waves through a storm

Markets taking a tumble didn't do my Isa investments any favours but the crucial mistake I made was looking in the first place. Sharp falls worry investors, but corrections are natural. Markets don't rise in a straight line and big down days will always come along, so I should expect this to happen and be willing to ride it out. The important thing is not to make rash decisions - here are my tips to do so.

SMALL CAP MOVERS: Eye-tracking specialist Seeing Machines captures market's attention

Why is AIM so terrible at recognising potential, let alone putting a realistic value on it - even as it is crystallising? A case in point: Seeing Machines (up 7 per cent this week).

Britain's WORST savings accounts named and shamed... so is YOURS on SYLVIA MORRIS'S list of shame?

Not even one of the duff deals exceeds 2%, despite the Bank of England base rate having stood at 5.25% for 12 months. Twenty-five accounts pay 1% or less.

A messy garden could knock tens of thousands off your house price: Here's how to tidy yours up with minimal fuss

If you are planning to sell your home, you may want to get the hedge trimmer and garden shears out. An untidy garden typically results in offers that are £33,720, or more than 12%, below the asking price, new research claims. This is Money examines why the garden is so important to a home sale, and outlines the five steps you can take to keep yours in check and ready for viewings.

This is Money podcast

What do buyers look for at a house viewing? Heat maps reveal their eyeballs linger on all the WRONG things

Some Britons are spending less time viewing their next home than test driving a car - and they are also honing in on all the wrong things. Zoopla tracked the eyeballs of people viewing houses, and discovered most eye up decorations and furnishings - while missing things that could be crucial.

Mortgage rate cuts continue: HSBC launches best-buy five-year fix below 4% but Barclays is set to undercut it

HSBC became the third lender to reintroduce a sub-4 per cent five-year fixed deal, following mortgage rate cuts by Nationwide and NatWest in recent days.

House prices up in July, says Halifax as falling mortgage rates reignite property market

House prices expected to continue on a 'modest upward trend' for the rest of the year, according to Halifax.

'Don't book that world cruise yet': DWP leaves bereaved families hanging over mystery state pension payouts

Families are being told their late relatives could be owed arrears then left in limbo for months by the Department for Work and Pensions. The amounts involved are not revealed, leaving recipients of letters mystified as to what sums they might eventually receive. Over the past few years, vast errors have led to payouts running into many tens of thousands of pounds, and in some cases awards of more than £100,000.

The legal risks of living with a partner unmarried? We bust the myths with ex-judge STEPHEN GOLD's cohabiting quiz

What rights do cohabiting partners have after a split, and do 'common law' spouses really exist? In part one of a new guide, Stephen Gold debunks common misconceptions.

Banks slash savings rates following base rate cut: The 100 accounts that have ALREADY had interest reduced

Rate cuts are usually bad news for savers, as banks reduce the interest paid on their savings accounts. We look at some of the rates which have taken a hit.

I asked mail order firm to stop writing to my late wife - now I think she's won £7,000: SALLY SORTS IT

My wife used to buy clothing from the mail order retailer Afibel. She died in April last year, but sales brochures and letters continued to arrive for her by post. I returned them all, marking them 'customer deceased', but they didn't stop. In the November brochure there was an announcement that Afibel was still seeking the winner of a £7,000 cash prize.

NS&I launches new two and five-year fixed-rate bonds for first time since 2009: How good are the rates?

The Treasury-backed savings bank has launched new two- and five-year fixed-rate versions of its British Savings Bonds for the first time in 15 years. It has also boosted the rate on its existing three-year British Savings Bonds, but for new savers only. We look at what the rules are on the accounts and how they stack up against other deals on the market.

Banks slash savings rates following base rate cut: The 100 accounts that have ALREADY had interest reduced

Rate cuts are usually bad news for savers, as banks reduce the interest paid on their savings accounts. We look at some of the rates which have taken a hit.

Why the pound is outperforming its rivals - and what it means for YOUR holidays, cash and shares

Stock markets have been plunging and the new Labour chancellor has been painting a dire picture of the economy. But Sterling is the best-performing currency this year.

Mortgage rates fall after Bank of England cut: NatWest slashes deals and now offers cheapest five-year fix

Mortgage rates have continued to fall following the Bank of England's decision to reduce the base rate, with NatWest the latest lender to cut its prices. Lenders began to reduce mortgage rates in the weeks leading up to last Thursday's decision, which was the first time the Bank had cut interest rates in over four years. And that has continued as NatWest, Virgin Money, MPowered, Halifax, Leeds Building Society and Skipton Building Society have all made reductions in recent days.

EXCLUSIVEStore First investment scandal victims targeted by scammers sending fake FSCS letters

Criminals have been sending scam letters to people who invested in Store First pods, This is Money can reveal.

Britain's big banks must be better prepared for a financial crisis, Bank of England warns

Barclays, HSBC, Lloyds and Standard Chartered were among those told that they need to be more prepared for a potential failure.

MORE BUSINESS & MARKETS NEWS

High heel designer Manolo Blahnik on the back foot amid sales slump

Manolo - worn by Sarah Jessica Parker's character in Sex And The City and model Hailey Bieber (pictured) - revealed sales hit £91.2m in 2023. That was down 10 per cent from the year before. Profits also tumbled by a third to £13.2m. The brand is suffering from the downturn in high-end fashion spending, driven by weak performance in the US and China.

Bellway sales buffered by 'moderation' in mortgage rates as housebuilder eyes return to growth next year

Bellwway's chief executive Jason Honeyman said 'challenging operating conditions' had continued to hit the firm's bottom line.

Olympic challenge for TV as pay-for-view streaming services step up their performance: ALEX BRUMMER

Pay-for view of maximum hours of Olympic broadcasting is a new phenomenon, which offers a graphic illustration of how broadcasting is changing.

BP pushes ahead with Teesside hydrogen plants despite ditching green agenda elsewhere

The FTSE 100 oil major has entered the final stages of negotiations with the Government for one of the biggest blue hydrogen production facilities in the UK.

Blow to rich expats in Italy as Meloni doubles foreign wealth tax amid squeeze on public finances

Italian Prime Minister Giorgia Meloni (pictured) is currently looking to raise to more revenue amid a squeeze on Italy's public finances.

YOUR MONEY ESSENTIALS

The pensioners who will be hit hardest by losing the winter fuel payment - and what they can do

Linda Kendall (left), from Essex, feels she has been picked on unfairly by the Chancellor (inset) and will face major difficulties to keep warm without her winter fuel payment. Meanwhile Brian Ashton (right) from Nottingham is anxious about his beloved dog Dougal who is on a special diet

I'm about to be made redundant: Can I put some of my £80,000 payout into my pension and pay less tax?

I know the first £30,000 is tax-free. Could I put the rest into a pension, and then take a tax-free lump sum in a couple of years' time?

Households face ANOTHER broadband price hike rip-off - while Ofcom looks the other way, says SAM BARKER

There is a storm coming for broadband prices, and the poorest households will struggle the most - so why isn't the regulator taking action?

The new '74' number plates BANNED for being too rude: These are the 365 registrations culled by the DVLA

The latest list of banned number plates deemed too rude for the road has been released by the DVLA - with everything from ULEZ to sex-related innuendos forbidden. Twice a year the DVLA faces the time-consuming task of sifting through any potentially offensive number plates that can be created using the new age identifier launched in March and September. In this instance, the '4' in '74' is causing an issue due to its similarity with the letter 'A'. See the full list of culled plates.

Britain will have a shortfall of 3,000 qualified EV mechanics by 2031 - and it could get worse

A major skills gap is being predicted for a workforce of mechanics trained to service and maintain the nation's EVs - with some parts of the country already undersupplied.

Car registrations continue to rise but likelihood of achieving binding EV sales targets looks increasingly bleak

In July, electric cars made up 18.5% of all sales. To meet EV sales targets set out in the Zero Emission Vehicle Mandate, this share needs to rise to 22% by the close of 2024.

How fast will interest rates fall - and what does it mean for you? This is Money podcast

Does the knife-edge base rate vote put us firmly in the way down or mean that we may have to wait some time for the next cut? We look at how far and fast will interest rates fall and it means for you, your savings and your mortgage. Plus, which taxes could rise, will pension tax relief be raided, and is house prices rising again a good thing?

Petition calling for rethink on axing Winter Fuel Payments for most pensioners closes in on quarter of a million signatures

Some 10m pensioners could lose the benefit , worth between £100 and £300 a year, and one to two million of the poorest of them may struggle to pay bills.

Can I cancel my holiday because I'm scared of the riots? DEAN DUNHAM replies...

I have a hotel booked in Plymouth this weekend but I now want to cancel due to the riots. Do I have the right to cancel and get my money back?

North-South divide for public EV chargers threatens to leave behind parts of the UK in electric revolution

Latest DfT figures show UK charging point installations are increasing overall, but the North of England is getting left behind, as the UK tracks behind targets. Further research from charger provider Believ shows a lack of formalised plans to boost EV infrastructure at local authority level is limiting installations.

Petrol should have been 5p-a-litre cheaper in July if retailers had been fair with drivers, says RAC

Fuel prices remained 'stubbornly static' in July as retailers charged inflated figures for both petrol and diesel despite wholesale prices justifying cuts at forecourts.

Ford Mustang Mach-E sets new Guinness World Record for travelling 570 miles on a single charge

A new world record has been set for the longest journey by an electric car on a single charge driving around England.

Can you help me find my long lost pension? How STEVE WEBB tracked down a pot worth thousands

The saga of trying to track down your missing pension has been going on for a decade, says Steve Webb. Our columnist joined the hunt last year, and has now finally reunited a reader with a valuable pot. Find out how he traced it - and how YOU can hunt your own lost pensions.

Why stock markets tumbled, what it means for investors - and what you should do

Global markets are suffering a huge sell-off sparked by heightened US recession fears after disappointing jobs data published last week.

BT's digital phone switch left residents in my retirement housing complex facing £2,000 bills EACH... here's why

People living in the Mallards retirement complex in Suffolk used to benefit from pull cords in every room that they could use to call for help in an emergency.

I missed my flight due to a delay at airport security of more than an hour - can I get compensation?

I missed my flight home due to queuing for more than an hour at the security queue, can I claim compensation? As a result, I had to book a new flight myself, is there a way that I can get my money back for the extra costs I have faced?

Car insurance costs are beginning to FALL - but motorists have still seen premiums rise 48% in two years

Premiums fell for the first time in more than two years between April and June 2024, but they are still much higher than motorists are used to.

How do I stop our nanny taking us for fools with high fees because we rely on her? VICKY REYNAL replies

Our babysitter has told us she's putting up her fees in September? I'm concerned that if we try to negotiate she'll just stop working for us.

Labour's tax attack could leave you much worse off, says JEFF PRESTRIDGE: Here's how to protect your wealth and pension NOW

It has taken a while for it to be extracted, but the cat is finally out of the bag. Last week, Chancellor of the Exchequer Rachel Reeves laid the groundwork for a gruesome attack on people's personal wealth - an assault she had defiantly refused to confirm during weeks of fervent electioneering.

Reeves will regret taking winter fuel payments from 10million pensioners, says JEFF PRESTRIDGE

My mailbox has been overwhelmed by readers spitting blood over Reeves' move. They feel that pensioners have been unfairly picked on.

Labour 'should raise Lifetime Isa limit': House price rises mean first-time buyers get stung for buying properties

The average house price in England has risen by £100,000 since 2015, but the property price limits for savers into the Help to Buy and Lifetime Isas have stayed the same.

Have I lost £7,000 I invested in Tramline Traders? TONY HETHERINGTON on ex-Nasa man John Burford's FCA mystery

I invested £7,000 and John Burford promised to buy and sell shares using his trading system, collecting a bonus for any increase in fund value. However, he says he has closed down the funds, and that the Financial Conduct Authority has taken control of them.

The race for space returns: Larger houses in demand as savvy families use softer prices to move up the ladder

The latest ONS house price data showed that detached and semi-detached houses rising more than flats and terraced houses. Verona Frankish, of estate agent Yopa says falling mortgage rates and rising incomes have resulted in an uptick in demand for larger homes, as buyers take advantage of cooler market values.

The first-time buyers' step-by-step guide to getting on the ladder: From what you can afford to getting the keys

We explain everything from how to work out your budget and find your ideal home, through to applying for your first mortgage and navigating the legal process.

Mortgages get cheaper at last - but should you be holding out for better rates? This is what the experts say

Mortgage holders battered by high borrowing costs can finally see light at the end of the tunnel after lenders cut rates last week.

Fraudsters stole my identity to take out a credit card and ruined my score: Why did it take so long to cancel?

Conor Burns discovered that fraudsters had taken out a Vanquis credit card in his name, using an old address. The criminals racked up a £1,531 bill which was passed on to debt collectors and adversely affected his credit score.

Nationwide launches dementia nurse clinics to help out its customers with health and financial advice

The building society plans to help over 100,000 people through a new partnership with charity Dementia UK.

Why has it taken Plum almost a month to transfer £16,000 from my cash Isa to my bank?

Why has my £16k transfer out of my Plum cash Isa to my bank account taken almost a month?

I attended university as a mature student, will I have to repay my loan during retirement?

I am currently 52 years old. I believe I must make repayments for 30 years , if I earn above a certain amount. Does this mean that when I retire, if my total pensions are above this limit, I will still have to make repayments?

Are older cars - not potholes - to blame for the rise in breakdowns? Average motor is now almost 10 years old

Analysis of Government data shows that the average age of registered cars in Britain has increased by 42% in the last 20 years.

Why coffee prices have skyrocketed - and Britain's 98million cups a day habit may only get more expensive

The prices of robusta and arabica beans, collectively responsible for about 99 per cent of global production, have shot up in the past year.

50 of the best funds and investment trusts: Our experts reveal their top ideas to grow your wealth

Investors are spoilt for choice when it comes to deciding on funds and investment trusts that can put their money to work. We asked trusted experts to recommend the best funds that cover different investment sectors - and included This is Money's selection of active and passive options too.

SAVE MONEY, MAKE MONEY: TIPS AND GUIDES

How to choose the best (and cheapest) DIY investing Isa - and our pick of the platforms

Choosing the right DIY platform is crucial but a wealth of choice and a variety of charges can leave investors scratching their heads. We pick some of the best. We pick some of the best. We also highlight why investing in an Isa makes sense, as it should protect your hopefully growing investments from tax forever.
